metadata.case_name: Appellant (partnership firm) v. State of U.P.

facts.text: The appellant is a partnership firm carrying on business as dealers in groundnuts, oil seeds and Arhar.

For the assessment years 1965-66 and 1966-67, the Sales-tax Officer, Rampur assessed the appellant to sales-tax on the turnover of the groundnuts oil manufactured by the appellant and to purchase tax on the turnover of the oil seeds and foodgrains.
The appellant unsuccessfully appealed against the assessment orders.
The appellant took up the matter in revision before the revising authority and substantially failed.

Aggrieved by the revising authority's decision, the appellant moved the High Court of Allahabad for a writ of certiorari quashing the levy of purchase tax imposed on purchases of oil seeds. The High Court rejected the petitions by judgment and decree dated December 18, 1968 in Civil Misc. Writ No. 4697 of 1968.
These are appeals by certificate from the Allahabad High Court judgment.

Notification No. ST-7122/X-900(16)-64 dated October 1, 1964 issued under Section 3-D(1) of the U.P. Sales Tax Act, 1948, imposing purchase tax of 2 paisa per rupee on the turnover of first purchases of oil seeds with effect from October 1, 1964.
Section 3AA incorporated into the Act on April 1, 1956.
Section 3-D incorporated into the Act on August 1, 1958.

legal_issues.text: Whether Section 3-D of the U.P. Sales Tax Act, 1948 is ultra vires the Constitution because excessive legislative power delegated to State Government and discriminates between registered dealers purchasing through licensed vs. unlicensed dealers.
Whether Notification No. ST-7122/X-900(16)-64 dated October 1, 1964 issued under Section 3-D imposing purchase tax on oil seeds is invalid as it contravenes Section 3AA of the Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 3-D is ultra vires the Constitution firstly because excessive legislative power delegated to State Government and secondly because it discriminates between registered dealers who made purchases through licensed dealers and those through unlicensed dealers.

Notification imposing purchase tax on oil seeds violates Section 3AA, which is a special provision for oil seeds providing for single-point sales tax to consumer, whereas Section 3-D is general; special excludes general.

respondent_arguments.text: Power conferred on State Government under Section 3-D(1) to levy purchase tax in place of sales tax on notified goods, subject to conditions therein; legislature left decision on sales vs purchase tax and point of levy to State Government considering varying factors.

Section 3-D(4) provides that on issue of notification under Section 3-D, no tax shall be levied under any other section in respect of notified goods; wide amplitude not cut down; Section 3AA's non-obstante clause covers only Sections 3 and 3A, not 3-D.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 3-D(4), Section 3AA U.P. Sales Tax Act, 1948

court_reasoning.text: First contention that Section 3-D ultra vires rejected for reasons in Civil Appeals Nos. 362 and 1692 of 1969 (Mls. Sita Ram Bishambhar Dayal etc. v. State of U.P.).
Section 3AA provides sales tax at single point of sale to consumer, rate not exceeding maximum in Section 15 Central Sales Tax Act, 1956; presumption of sale to consumer unless proved otherwise.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Analysis of Section 3AA: sales-tax, single-point levy to consumer.

court_reasoning.text: Section 3-D provides purchase tax on first purchases of notified goods; sub-section (4) states on notification under this section no tax under any other section for those goods.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Section 3-D later than 3AA; legislature aware but sub-s.(4) wide, covers goods in 3AA.

court_reasoning.text: Section 3AA non-obstante clause: 'Notwithstanding anything contained in section 3 or 3A' does not include Section 3-D; if intended to exclude 3-D, legislature could have said so explicitly.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No grounds to cut down power under Section 3-D(4).

court_reasoning.text: Allahabad High Court consistently held State can levy purchase tax under Section 3-D on goods covered by Section 3AA.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Court agrees with High Court view.

holdings.text: Section 3-D is not ultra vires the Constitution.
Notification under Section 3-D imposing purchase tax on oil seeds is valid and does not violate Section 3AA; Section 3-D(4) prevails over Section 3AA for notified goods.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mls. Sita Ram Bishambhar Dayal etc. v. State of U.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Reasons why Section 3-D not ultra vires

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Sales Tax Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Section 3-D authorizes purchase tax on first purchases of notified goods including oil seeds; sub-s.(4) excludes levy under other sections like 3AA once notified; 3AA limits sales tax to consumer sales.

statutes_cited.name: Central Sales Tax Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Maximum rate limit for tax under Section 3AA.

outcome.summary: The appeals challenging the levy of purchase tax on oil seeds under notification issued per Section 3-D as violative of Section 3AA fail; appeals dismissed upholding the assessments and High Court decision.

key_quotes.text: on the issue of a notification under this section no tax shall be levied under any other section in respect of the goods so notified.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key provision in Section 3-D(4) overriding other sections including 3AA.

key_quotes.text: The non-obstante clause does not take in S. 3-D. If the legislature intended to exclude the operation of S. 3-D, in respect of matters covered by S. 3AA, nothing would have been easier than to say so.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why Section 3AA does not prevail over Section 3-D.
